awd_titl_txt: CRII:CSR: Enabling High-Performance Deep Learning Computing System via Software and Hardware Co-Optimized Reconfiguration
awd_abstract_narration:
Deep learning (DL) technology has much success in today's artificial intelligence (AI) applications. However, executions of DL algorithms consume much computational and energy resources because of the large-scale data and complex computation models. The project addresses this challenge with a hardware and software co-optimization strategy. A high-performance deep learning system is enabled with the capability to select automatically the best parameter configurations of advanced algorithms based on the hardware architecture of the computing system.
 
The project seeks to solve a fundamental challenge of a DL based computing system where intensive computations are introduced while the computing resources and the real-time budget are limited. Task 1 proposes an algorithm-driven DL computing system configuration based on a full parameter deep learning compression and a hardware-friendly algorithm deployment. Task 2 investigates an architecture-driven DL computing system configuration based on DL computation performance profiling and modeling on various hardware architectures. The success of the project paves the design foundation of a DL based intelligence system by considering the constraints of data, algorithm, and hardware platform.

The project provides benefit to computational intelligence (CI), embedded systems, mobile intelligence, machine learning, and computing architecture. The project will further promote software and hardware co-development towards highly efficient intelligence systems for real-world artificial intelligence applications. The project will also benefit a wide range of communities by means of seminar broadcasts, a short course program, and children and high-school programs. The education plan will enhance existing curricula and pedagogy by integrating interdisciplinary modules with innovative teaching practices. 

The outcomes of the project, including data and experiments results, will be distributed in the form of journal articles, conference proceedings, workshops, invited presentations and student thesis. The results related with developed curriculum will also be published in appropriate education conferences. The simulators built for validation and simulation code will also be available to the public. Copies of these papers, presentations, models, simulation codes and course notes will be placed on a research page (http://if-lab.org/awards/crii2018) associated with this project.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Overview

Deep learning (DL) has performed as the main driving horsepower of the developing of artificial intelligence in the past decades. Evolved from conventional neural network and machine learning technology, DL involves many layers with complex structure and is particularly powerful in cognitive applications such as image and speech recognition, object detection, natural language processing, etc. However, executions of such DL algorithms are extremely computation and memory intensive. The computing efficiency of the intelligence system embodied by the DL algorithm and hardware platform is highly constrained. This challenge becomes more severe in the intelligence mobile system, which has a strict requirement in real-time response and energy budget. As such, how to design advanced algorithm with decreased computing resource demand and novel hardware with increased computing capacity to enable efficient intelligence system has become a common commitment of all the researchers in the community.

Intellectual Merit

Two major tasks were proposed to enable intelligence system with enhanced efficiency and accuracy in two perspectives – algorithm and hardware. Task 1 served as a software driven solution to achieve maximal computing efficiency and accuracy through exploring advanced DL algorithms and their deployment. Task 2 exploited architectural advancements in various DL computing platforms, such as GPU, processing-in-memory architecture to further enhance computing efficiency.

Major Outcomes:

The expected research outcome of the proposed project is an integrated algorithm/hardware co-design methodology that can address the computing challenges of general DL-based intelligence systems (e.g., mobile intelligence system), where intensive computation, communication, and storage are introduced while the computing resource, energy, and real-time budge are limited. It makes it possible to tailor the functionality of hardware platform of the intelligence system with enhance computing capacity, efficiency, as well as real-time realization. A holistic method composed of algorithm driven and architecture driven solutions was obtained by employing advanced algorithms with full parameter considered and novel computing platform.

1.     We investigated advanced algorithms on deep learning models, e.g., attention-based deep neural network (DNN) parameter reduction to improve DNN computing efficiency on computing platforms not only CPU and GPU but also novel DNN accelerators (e.g., ReRAM-based processing-in-memory (PIM) engine). We also delivered novel DNN deployment algorithms and architectural optimizations to adapt the advanced algorithm to hardware to enlarge the performance improvement.

2.     We explored algorithm-architecture co-development for high-performance deep learning computing on various computing platforms, such as GPU and novel ReRAM-based PIM accelerators. Specifically, we analyzed the computing performance and resource utilization of DNN executions on these platforms and developed novel DNN operations scheduling and architecture designs.

 These outcomes were well presented in publications in EDA domain.

 The key transformative aspect of these outcome is the success of the project leads a breakthrough of DNN computing performance on various computing platforms such as CPU, GPU, PIM accelerators. The results of the project built a solid foundation for the intelligence system design by considering the constrains from deep learning data, data processing algorithm, and computing platform.

Broader Impacts

Our research benefited computation intelligence, mobile intelligence, machine learning and computer architecture through close collaboration with diverse academia and industry groups. The study advanced the societies by guiding software and hardware co-development and co-optimization toward building ultra-highly efficient intelligence system for the real-world artificial intelligence applications.

Benefited by this project, the education plan well enhanced existing curricula by integrating the research outcomes with courses CMSC 611 Advanced Computer Architecture and CMSC 491/691 Special Topic in Neuromorphic Computing. Several Ph.D. students with one of them is female student were supported by the project and some of them graduated and started their careers in industry and academia.

Moreover, the broader impact of the project is well reached by wide result dissemination via research publications, seminars, workshops, short courses, modern media, and upcoming technology transfer activities.
